description:
Fomitiporia mediterranea MF3/22 is a species of wood-decay fungus that belongs to the Hymenochaetaceae family. It is a polypore fungus, which means it has a fruiting body with a pore surface on the underside.

This species is known to be found in the Mediterranean region, hence the name "mediterranea." It is a wood-decaying fungus, meaning it decomposes and breaks down the structural components of wood, primarily cellulose and lignin.

Fomitiporia mediterranea MF3/22 is considered a saprotroph, as it obtains its nutrients by decomposing dead or decaying organic matter, in this case, the wood of various tree species. The fungus produces perennial, woody fruiting bodies that can persist for several years, typically growing on the trunks or branches of living or dead trees.

The fungus is known to cause a type of wood rot called white rot, where it selectively decomposes the lignin component of the wood, leaving behind a whitish, fibrous material. This process can lead to the weakening and eventual deterioration of the affected wood.

Further research may be needed to fully understand the ecological role, distribution, and potential impact of Fomitiporia mediterranea MF3/22 in its natural environment.
